The Cuba Digital and Telecommunications Advancement Act of 2015 (Cuba DATA Act) was introduced on May 20, 2015, authorizing the exportation of consumer communications devices to Cuba and the provision of telecommunications services. It also repealed certain provisions of the Cuban Democracy Act of 1992 and the Cuban Liberty and Democratic Solidarity (LIBERTAD) Act of 1996. Additionally, the Cuban Military Transparency Act, introduced as S. 1489/H.R. 2937, aimed to prohibit financial transactions with certain Cuban military entities. Section 5 of S. 1489 introduced on June 3, 2015, would have included rewards for information leading to the arrest or conviction of individuals involved in the 1996 attack on a U.S. aircraft by the Cuban military. Section 6 would have required the Attorney General to coordinate with INTERPOL to locate and arrest U.S. fugitives in Cuba, including former members of the Cuban military. Sections 7 and 8 would have mandated reports to Congress on the economic and foreign relationship roles of Cuban military entities MINFAR and MININT, as well as on the use of confiscated property by these entities.
